author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
It could be akin to a mix of EIP-3756 and the Bitcoin halving schedule (or the difficulty bomb): hard-code in a gas limit reduction at a particular date (or cumulative gas consumption). I'm not sure whether a step function or a tapering off would be preferable, but it feels safer to set a lower bound on the upper gas limit (rather than a constantly decreasing upper (gas) limit).

The real issue in my eyes seems to be breaking the expectation of 'no changes until the merge is done'.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: I have wondered whether it'd be ethical to temporarily increase L1 compute costs along with EIP-4488, to create a surge of L2 adoption.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
Eventually L2 volume will crowd out L1 transactions, and there may be plenty of (economically) stranded assets on L1. 

The alternative idea of 'Force transfer into a minimal withdraw-only rollup' is also rather attractive [https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/some-medium-term-dust-cleanup-ideas/6287].
